audio_caption: The audio clip begins with quiet, gentle piano music that evokes a contemplative mood. A male speaker then begins to discuss architecture, stating it has become "a commodity" produced by "highly skilled and talented artists" instead of serving a broader public need. He critiques the "rise of the starchitects," accusing them of prioritizing large-scale sculptures without fully considering how people will use, perceive, or safely enjoy those places. The piano music resumes quietly as the clip ends.

The clip starts with a male speaker arguing that much of what has been celebrated in architecture has been a kind of "self-indulgence" on the part of architects who have "often been dismissive" of their clients and their clients' real needs. The speaker then claims that these architects have looked at buildings that have leaked or have not worked effectively, or have not provided the kind of environmental security that they ought to have provided.  He finishes by saying, "we've made stars of those individuals, I think to the detriment of the public at large."

A man speaks in a calm, reflective tone, commenting positively on a shift in architecture schools, noting how students are "asking for a more socially conscious and a more environmentally conscious kind of architecture," one that "really serves human needs."

The clip begins with a single male speaker, reflecting on architecture as a "small and privileged profession." He notes the limited number of licensed architects in the United States and the lack of diversity within the field, stating "fewer than a quarter of all of the licensed architects... are women", and that "fewer than 6% are people of color". He continues in a similar thoughtful tone to discuss how this demographic tends to reward itself for its work.

The clip features a single male speaker with a somewhat critical tone, observing that despite "about 115 architecture schools in the United States," awards tend to favor graduates from a "small handful, maybe a half a dozen," primarily from the Northeast and Northwest coast. He continues, saying that magazines celebrating architects focus on a limited group, often not even American, who do "particular narrow kind of work for wealthy clients." The speaker appears slightly irritated.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing wealth in the United States, commenting that wealth has "gone into supporting a kind of design" emphasizing style over substance. He critiques designs created in recent years, noting "they may look great" but may not fit or function optimally. The clip ends with another man speaking.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing societal issues related to design, such as cars, electrical instruments, cities, and buildings, alluding to excessive energy consumption and a focus on individual desires over societal needs. His tone is reflective and critical, indicating a concern for the consequences of current design practices. There are no background sounds or music in the audio.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a "point of crisis" and how "things designed over the last 15, 20 years have failed us". He mentions that these things may be "using too much energy" or "breaking down excessively", spoken with a concerned tone. He concludes that they "are not meeting the kinds of needs we would have anticipated".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a challenge in design: to recalibrate design thinking and incorporate a new value set, one that emphasizes real human needs over style. The speaker speaks in a serious and thoughtful tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on the privilege of working in architectural and environmental education, particularly with current students. He notes the increasing focus on students' technical skills, enabling them to work faster and smarter with more information and diverse materials. The speaker expresses that this progress is "wonderful".

The audio features a male speaker describing how students in recent years are "much more committed to social service" and "issues of service to those who have traditionally been underserved." The speaker speaks in a conversational and enthusiastic tone.

The audio clip consists of one male speaker in a conversational tone. He discusses the architectural style of Frank Gehry and the desire of other architects to emulate it by "creat[ing] great sculptures in the landscape," noting the irrelevance of whether these sculptures were functional. He states that the era of using "aerospace engineering to come up with forms that hadn't been built before" is over.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing how students are considering work in specific areas, focusing on the needs of people in refugee camps and individuals worldwide. The speaker emphasizes the need for affordable and sustainable living. He notes that students push design schools to rethink faculty perspectives on the environment and prioritize long-term sustainability for clients. Finally, the sound of a sewing machine starts.
